alert.note: Alert for Florence (Wisconsin) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS GreenBay (East Central Wisconsin - Green Bay)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 15 at 11:26PM CDT until April 20 at 11:00PM CDT by NWS GreenBay
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Wisconsin...Michigan... Menominee River near Vulcan affecting Menominee, Dickinson and Marinette Counties. Menominee River near Niagara affecting Florence, Menominee, Dickinson and Marinette Counties. Menominee River near Florence affecting Florence, Dickinson and Iron Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Wisconsin...Michigan... Brule River near Commonwealth affecting Florence, Forest, Dickinson and Iron Counties. For the Menominee River...including Florence, Vulcan, Niagara... Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THURSDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Menominee River near Florence. * WHEN...Until late Thursday evening. * IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Floodwaters affect homes along Runbers road in Florence County. This stage compares to a flow rate of 10600 cubic feet per second at the Brule Dam. At 9100 cfs, floodwaters affect a seasonal home on a private drive off Runbers Road. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 PM CDT Saturday the stage was 11.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:00 PM CDT Saturday was 11.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall to 10.1 feet early Monday afternoon. It will then rise to 10.3 feet Tuesday evening. It will fall below flood stage late Thursday morning to 8.4 feet Friday morning. It will then rise to 8.9 feet Friday evening. It will fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 11.3 feet on 04/29/1921. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Sunday afternoon.
